sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

row.cell: Item paied vnto the mvsicions ffor Christenmas anno xj° Elizabethae Regine
Item to the carpenter for mendynge tables and trestles this winter broken with revelles at sundrye tymes
Item for iiij staffe torches agaynst allhollowtide and candlemas
Item to the carpenter for mendynge formes and tables in the hall after the great Showe and newe fotinge most of the trestles
Item paid to the Mvsicions for Christmas tyme ffor the howse by the appoyntment of Master Treasorer the Some of
Item vnto the Mvsicions for Christmas Anno xvo Regni Regine the Some of

div.head: f 70v (30 January) (Pension orders)
div.ab: Also it is further ordered that Mr Shutt one of the Tresorers shall paye to the Steward six poundes for Mr Revell his two last vacacions and eight poundes for iiij weikes allowed to the gentlemen at xl s. a weike & xxvj s. viij d. for the musicions in christynmas whiche somme comethe to xv li. viij vj s. viij d.

div.head: f 78v (27 November) (Pension orders)
div.ab: yt is Lykewyse agryed yat viij li. shalbe allowed vnto yeeyee: for ye; first e supralinear; one e is superfluous gentilmen for the mayntinance of ther comons betwen thend of this terme & the beginnyng of the next & xxvj s. viij d. to the mvsycions in tyme of Chrystemas yf yatyat: possibly yt, ie, it be not thought perrillous for the Sycknes & the sum to be paid by Mr Anger

div.head: f 84Av (25 November–26 January) (Treasurer’s expenses and allowances)

row.cell: Paide to Thomas Casson Steward 20 December Anno xxo Elizabeth towardes the mayntenaunce of the comons in Christemas tyme & of ye mvsycions
ix li. vj s. viij d.presumably £8 for Christmas Commons plus 26s 8d to the musicians at Christmas

div.head: ff 144–4v (5 February) (Paid to Ladyman)
div.note: Only the eighth item cited here (p 103, ll.1–3), and by implication the seventh, are certainly associ- ated with a play.

row.cell: ffor x fott of borde to amende the gate against candelmas and for xxxij fott to make an ende of the pale
ffor C of nayles about that worke
ffor a dayes worke in doinge of it
ffor ij quarters to amende the tressells and the formes in the hall against Candlemas day
ffor Six fott of borde for yt
ffor a plancke to make a forme in the hall the morrowe after Candellmas day
for fower single quarters to make the same forme newe and to amende other formes Broken at the playe
ffor a dayes worke about it
Item for Bordes Cut for stoles and seates for the play at ShorvetydeShorvetyde: 5–7 February 1580/1
Item for j hundrethe of sixe peny neyles
Item for j half dayes work for ij of the Carpenters men about the seates
Item for half a dayes worke for ij of the Carpenters men in mending and settinge vp the Tables and formes in the hall after the playe
Item to the pewterer for vessell lost now at Candlemas videlicet on Charger one iij li. platter 4 myddell platters viij sallett dyshes one pye platt on sawser on great wrowght dyshe weying xxxij li.
Item paid to the musicions this yere more then I received

div.head: f 177v (28 January 1582/3–31 January 1583/4) (Money laid out)
div.note:
A connection between the four song-books and Gray’s Inn revels is suggested by a similar reference in the Gray’s Inn Ledger Books 1584–5 (p 108, l.3). After this year accounts occur not in the Pension Book but in the Ledger Book.
Scholars consulted on these song-books (Steven W. May and musicologists David Fallows and John Milsom) agree that there is no obvious candidate for an English secular song-book of this date available in multiple (including printed) copies, but they note the possibility of foreign chansons or madrigals, arrangements of metrical psalms, contemporary five-part music, second-hand prints or manuscripts, bespoke manuscripts, or music written into books printed as blank scores (see STC: 7567.5).

row.cell: Item to the musicians for their wages

div.head: f 184 (31 March 1583–19 April 1584) (Disbursements)
div.note: For another reference to books for singing, see preceding note.

row.cell: Item of ij s. vj d. paied for iiij Songe Bookes for the gentlemen to sing by

div.head: f 187 (26 November) (Pension orders)
div.note: Againest all disorder in ye Cristmas teime
div.ab: At this Pention it is ordered that from henceforthe no gentleman of this Socyetie nor any other person by the appoyntment choyse or assent of any gentleman of this house shall in tyme of Cristmas or any other tyme take vpon hym or vse the Name place or commaundement of Lord or any such other lyke or break open any chamber or disorderlye molest or abuse any fellowe or officer of this howsse within the precincte of the same vpon payne to be vtterlye expulsed the for the abuse or disorder against any fellow of this howsse & of being put out of commons for abuse of any officer

div.head: f 192 (23 January) (Pension orders)
div.note: The ‘comedy or shew’ (p 110, l.39) was presumably the lost Roman comedy called, for want of a formal title, ‘Sylla Dictator’: see Appendix 6.2. As many as three plays may have been performed over the year, as set out in Appendix 8.
div.ab: Att this pencion there was allowed out of the stocke of the house, towardes the charges of the comedy or shew sett forth by the gentlemen of the house this last christenmas xxtie markes with this proviso that ffrom henceforth noe allowanc, be made out of the stock of the house for such lyke occasion vnlesse yt ryste vpon some such charge, agreed vpon by the reders of the house before;And this xx markes is to be payd out of the admyttance money.

div.head: f 198v (28 January) (Pension orders)
div.note: The musicians recovered only £7 of the £8 plus 26s 8d that they normally received for their activities over Christmas.
Musiticions allowed
div.ab: Att thisie, at this pension there is allowed to the musitians vij li. for the losse of the last christenmas Lykewise for the banquett made by mr Trott mr Smyth & mr Lamploughe v li. is allowed.

div.head: f 215v (11 February) (Pension orders)
div.note: The ‘sportes & shewes this Shrovetyde2–4 March 1594/5 at the Court before the Queenes Maiestie’ were doubtless related to The Masque of Proteus (see printed Inns of Court Volume 2, Appendix 6.1).
div.ab: It ys orderyd that Mr William Mills shalbe intreatyd to delyuer vnto Mr William Iohnson & Mr Edward Morrys the some of one hvndryd markes to be layd out & bestowyd vppon the Gentlemen for ther sportes & shewes this Shrovetyde8m/ Shrovetyde, shrovetyd, shrouetide: 2–4 March 1594/5 at the Court before the Queenes Maiestie, the same hvndryd markes to be payd agayne to the sayd Mr Mills hys Executors or Assignes before thend of the next Term

div.note: a Tax for shewes & sportes before her Maiestie at shrouetide

row.cell: At this pencion it is ordred yat every Reader of this house towardes the charges of the shewes and desportes before her Maiestie at shrovetyd last past shall pay tenne shillinges & euerye Auncient vj s. viij d. & euerye vterbarester v s. euerye other gentleman of this societie iiij s. before thend of this terme whether they be in comons or lying in the house or About the same house & this collection to contynew tyll thend of the next terme And the house towardes the Aforsaid charges is to Allowe out of the publique Stock of the said house the some of

div.head: f216 (21 May)
div.note:
All gentlemen out of the Commons warned to come into Commones & beare share of all Common Charges
"Nota"
div.ab: Att this pencion it is ordered that in Respect of the great charges at this tyme lying vpon the house and your Exceeding great necligences in discharging of your dueties that all those whose names be subscribed being ordynariely lyers out of comons & all others of this societie being in or About London shall before the last day of this instant moneth of may resort into comons & discharge suche money and other dueties as be due or Assessed vpon them & euerye of them by thorders of this house viz comons pencions vacations fire roulles vnto Mr Doctors intertaynment toward the charges of sportes before her Maiestie and all other dueties whatsoever otherwise from thensforth to be out of comons and so to remayne if they reforme not themselves vntill the last day of Iune next comynge and who so shall not before that tyme conforme himself therin to be then ^csforth no longer fellowe of this societie but ipso facto to be expelled the same

persName.n: Robert Rich; check: may be Baron Rich

div.head: f 216v (1 July)
div.ab: At this pencion it is ordered that all these gentlemen whose names are subscribed shalbe out of this hou societie of this house for ther non payment of Comons and other dueties and for the breache of An order mayd in pencion the xxjth of May Anno 37o last past for the reformation of those and sundry disorders being publiquely set vp in the vsuall place of the said hall for yat purpose
div.note: Mr Mills ^lent the House C marks
div.ab: At the same pencion it is ordered that Mr LanyMr Lany: treasurer the recever of thadmittance money shall pay vnto Mr Mills out of the same Admittance Money the some of xl li. over and besides the four pound remaynyng in the handes of the said Mr Mills for the admission of Mr Evers into the fellowshippe of this house which money the said Mr Mills receaved of the said Mr Evers all which is toward the discharg of the some of A C markes C Markes disbursed by the said Mr Mills at the instance of the readers of this house towardes the disportes ^before her maiestie at shrovetyd last past2–4 March 1594/5

div.head: f 217 (8 July)
div.note: The remanant of Mr Mills money Lent allowed
div.ab: The remanant of the debt due to Mr Mills being xvij li. vj s. viij d. yt ys ordred that Mr Nightingale shall make payment of to the said Mr Mills out of the Admyttance money/

div.head: f 225 (10 November) (Pension orders)
div.note: Could the reference to 34 Elizabeth (l.22) (1591–2) be a mistaken reference to 37 Elizabeth, 1594–5, and the events described in Gesta Grayorum (see Appendixes 1 and 6.1)?
div.ab: It is ordred that Mr LanyMr Lany: treasurer shall pay vnto Mr Iohnson out of the admittance money the somm of iij li. xvij s. & x d. in full discharge of all the Charges remanent for the Christmas sportes Anno 34 Anno Elizabethe Regine

div.head: f 234v (4 July) (Pension orders)
div.ab: It is also ordered that the arerages of the Musicians money beinge vj li. xij s. shalbee likewise paide by Master Tresorer if hee have money sufficient in his handes

div.head: f 245 (11 February) (Pension orders)
div.ab: Item there is allowed vnto the Musicions in respect they had entred into the Christmas service & were discharged therefore ther is allowed vnto them vij li.

div.head: f 251 (10 February) (Pension orders)
div.ab: Att this Pencion yt is ordered that the Steward shall paye vnto the Musicians vij li. for their service this Last Christmas./

div.head: f 261v (7 February) (Pension orders)
div.note: Mr Michell was ‘the Musition of the howse’ at Gray’s Inn (see printed Inns of Court, volume 1, p 190, l.26).
div.ab: Mr Michell & the musicions are allowed xl s. for their attendance of Candlemas daie, albeit they then did not performe their service in respect of the late infection

div.head: f 276v (4 February) (Pension orders)
div.ab: It is ordred that the xl s. which the Steward is to paie to the Musicions shalbee made eight powndes to bee payde by master Treasorer

div.head: f 278v (27 November) (Pension orders)
div.ab: Att this pencion the Musicions are allowed to haue 4 li. for their wages from Alhallowtide vntill Christmas to bee paid by the Treasorer

div.head: f 287 (24 January) (Pension orders)
div.note: for mussick
div.ab: Att this pencion 3 li. 6 s. 8 d. is allowed to the musitions in regard they did not serve here att hallowtide nor any tyme els the last terme by reason of the sicknes and were dischardged of their service here this last Christmas

div.head: f 298 (27 January) (Pension orders)
div.note:
The ‘maske’ (p 148, l.11), Beaumont’s Masque of the Inner Temple and Gray’s Inn, was performed in the Banqueting House, Whitehall, on 20 February 1612/13, following the marriage of Princess Elizabeth and the count palatine. The current order seems designed to guarantee that Gray’s Inn will raise funds at the same rate as its partner, the Inner Temple.
The ‘maskinge apparrel’ (p 149, l.37) featured in this and subsequent entries was worn by Inns of Court gentlemen in their equestrian procession or ‘riding’: see Introduction, p xxvi–xxvii.
An assesse toward a Maske.

div.ab: At this Pencion the Readers ar prised every man 4 li. the Ancientes and such as ar at this tyme to be Called ancientes at 2 li. 10 s. the baristers at 40 s. the Studientes at 20 s. towardes the maske out of which monye [so much] so much to be Collected as the Inner Temple doth alowe

Mr William Gerrad electted Treasorer ffor the Maske and such thinges to be bought as Master SolicitorFrancis Bacon shall thinke ffitt and the Prises to be concidered of by the overseers appointed all Prises as they shall alowe of to be paid by Master Solicitors warrente

div.head: f 298v (4 February)
div.note: euery gentleman to pay his taxacion to the maske, or to loose chamber or expelled.
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that every gentleman of this societie taxed to the Charge of the Kings Maske having a Chamber in the howse shall not by munday nextmunday next: 8 February 1612/13 pay his taxacion his Chamber is ipso ffacto fforffeated & to be sesed to the vse of the howse and yf any man taxed havinge noe Chamber shall not pay his taxacion as afforesaid is ipso ffacto expulsed the howse

ffurther it is Ordered that if the taxe alredie made for the maske will not be sufficient to discharge the [howse] same then it is nowe Ordered that at the next Pencion ffurther Order shalbe taken for Leviinge of so much as shalbe suffitient beffore befforbeffore beffor: dittography saterday com senightaterday com senight: 20 February 1612/13 and a Pencion to be holden one munday nextmunday next: 15 February 1612/13 in that behalffe

div.head: f 299 (8 February)
div.note: Voluntary Contribution toward the maske beside the Tax.
div.ab: It is agreed at this Pencion that it shalbe concidered what gentlemen are fitt to Contribute voluntary towardes the mask besides the taxe allredi sett & then Collectores to be assined ffor the gatheringe of the voluntary Contribucion

div.head: f 299v (2 March) (Cupboard order)
div.ab: Wher it was Ordered that wheras Mr Hansbie hath lent 40 li. & Mr Wallor & Mr Mosley ether of them 30 li. for the generall vse of Graies Inne towardes the discharginge of the maske that every of these gentlemen shall have ther severall somes of money repaid them againe by the howse at the end of the terme next ensuinge

And it is ffurther Ordered that if any gentlemen shall herafter Lend any money for this purpose that he or thay shall have ther money repaid them againe by the howse at the end of the next terme as afforesaid

It is Ordered at this Pencion that they which ^have not paid their money seaced vppon them towardes the Kinges Maske accordinge to the fformer Order shall pay the same beffore the assention day next13 May 1613 vnto the severalie Collectors therof, vnder Losse of ther Chambers that have Chambers in the howse whether they be howse Chambers or Lease Chambers and vnder paine of Expulsion of such out of the Howse as have noe Chambers, Neverthelesse such as nether are nor shalbe in Commons nor in nor neer the towne this terme nor any part therof shall have Libertie to pay their said moneis vntill the second saterday in the next terme26 June 1613 vppon the penalties afforesaid

div.head: f300 (12 May)
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that Mr Barker one of the Readers of this howse shalbe ffreed and discharged from all taxes & paimentes heerafter to be made for and towardes the maske & solemnities in Regard that he hath willingly paid iiij li. accordinge to the Levie mad the Last terme when he was absent

div.head: ff 301–1v (18 May) (Cupboard order)
div.ab: It was Ordered that the gentlemen Late Actors in the maske at the Court shall bring in all ther maskinge apparrel which they had of the Howse Charge at or beffore the first next pencion in the next terme or els the value therof as the Readers then shall thinke ffitt

It is ordered at this Pencion that every one of the Revelors in the Late Maske at the Court shall bringe in ther masking apparrell and deliver it to Sir ffrancis Evre at his Chamber in Graies Inne one Saterdaye next19 June 1613 or before or els euery one of the said Revelors makinge defavlt therof shall pay vnto the same Sir ffrancis Evre at his Chamber afforesaid the full some xxx li. one Munday next21 June 1613 before eleven of the Clocke in the forenone to the vse of the Societie of Graies Inne in Leue of the same apparrell or els Incure such censure as may ensue.

It is also Ordered at this Pencion that wheras by Order mad in Pencion the eight day of Maye 1613 it was Ordained that every gentleman of this Societie then being in Or nere the towne should paye his taxacion imposed vppon him by assencion day then next affter which is now past13 June 1613 and also that every gentleman of this Societie then not in nor nere the Towne so as he by intendment Could not have convenient notice in so short a tyme to accomplish the Order afforesaid should Likewyse performe the same by the second saterday in Trinitie terme then next insuinge26 June 1613 which is Likewyse Now past Therfore in respect defavlt is made by divers gentlemen of this Societie as well then present as absent it is Now Ordered at this Pencion that the Pencioner doe ffourthwith execut the said Order ffor Seisinge of Chambers both vppon such as were then absent by reason ther tyme given them is now expired & also vppon those that were then present having not paid ther seuerall taxacions according to ther severall rankes and that without further procrastinacion or delay

div.head: f 302 (22 June)
div.note: for Bringing in the Masking suits.
div.ab: At this Pencion it is allso Ordered that wheras before the Maske Lateley performed at the Court before his Maiestie yt was by the Order of this Howse as by the Orders of all the other Howses of Court amongst them for themselves Ordered that the Maskers should affter the performance of that service bring in ther Maskings suites wherby some profitt might be made of them to ease the great Charge which was expended and in great parte resteth yet vnpaid And wheras the Maskers of the Howse fforbearinge to bringe them in according to the said Order yt was affter the severall answeres of some of them recorded in or pay 30 li. a peece which cost the house C markes a peece. Open pencion againe Ordered that they should bringe them in by a Certaine day of this terme or ells every one of them makinge default to aunswere Thirtie poundes in Leuie therof every of ther said sutes having Cost the Howse above a Hundred Markes which they have Contemptuously neglectted and refused to performe, Albeit none of them did Contribute any thing to the said Charge as also were alowed all other ther necessarie Charges expended theraboutes wherfore for as much as It is not thought ffitt that any gentlemen of this Howse should make profitt of the howse in that manor in particuler as also that if the said Maskinge apparell should not be brought in accordinge to the Order ther must be a generall newe taxacion of the hole howse to paie the severall debtes behind & vnpaide
div.note: The Maskers refused, although none of them paid toward the tax, & had all theire other charges borne necessarie theraboutes. therfore put out of Commons &c./
div.ab: It is therfore ordered that everye of the said severale maskers nowe beinge in towne shall for ther said Contemptes be presently Cast into Commons and put out againe and so to Continewe accordinge to the Order of the Howse vntill they ^have performed the said Last Order And that such of them as ^ar now owt of Towne shall performe the same Order at or before Hollamas next at which tyme such of them as shalbe found failinge in the performance of the said Order that is to say aswell those that are Cast into Commons and out againe to the others, are then fourthwith expelled this societie for ther willfull Contemptes of the governmente of this Howse and ther Inconciderate dealinge and the generall wronges to every member therof
It is thought ffitt by these Readers whose names ar vnder written that the draught of the Order towchinge the Maskers apparrell be revewed and the publishinge of it be staied tell ⎡the⎤ next terme

div.head: ff 303–3v (15 November) (Pension orders)
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that wheras at a pencion holden the 22 of

Iune 1613 for the bringinge in of the Maskinge apparrell it was Ordered as foloweth that is to say, it is Ordered that wheras befor⟨.⟩ the maske latly performed at the Court before his Maiestie it was by the Order of this howse as by the Orders of all the other howses of Court amongst them for them selves Ordered that the Maskers should after the performance of that service bring in ther Maskinge sutes wherby some profit might be made of them to ease the greate Charge which was expended and in great parte resteth yet vnpaid & wheras the Maskers of the howse forbearinge to bringe them in accordinge to the said Order it was after the severall aunswers of som of them recorded in Open Pencion againe & againe Ordered that they should bring them in by a Certaine day of this terme or els every one of them making default to aunswer thirtie poundes in Lew therof every of ther said suites having Cost the howse above a hundred Marks which they haue Contemptuously neglected and refused to performe albeit none of them did Contribute any thinge to the said Charge as also were allowed all other ther necessarie Charges expended theraboutes wherfore for asmuch as itt is not thought fitt that any gentlemen of this howse should make profitt of the howse in that manor in particulor as also that if the said Maskinge apparrell should not be brought in accordinge to the said Order ther must be a generall new taxacion of the hole howse to pay the severall debtes behind and vnpaid, Yt is therfor Ordered that every of the said severall Maskers nowe being in towne shall for ther said contemptes be presently Cast into Commons and put out againe & so to Continewe accordinge to the Order of this howse vntill they have performeperforme: for performed the said last Order and that such of them as ar now owt of towne shall performe the same Order at or before Hallomas Next at which tyme such of them as shalbe found failinge in the performance of the said Order that is to say as well those that are Cast into Commons and out againe as the others Ar then fourthwith expelled the societie for ther willfull Contemptes of the government of this howse and ther Inconciderat dealing and the generall wronges to every member therof |

Now at this Pencion the said former Order is fully Confirmed and further it is Ordered that forasmuch as the tyme is expired within which the same should have been performed that the said former Order shall neverthelesse by or before Munday nextMunday next: 22 November 1613 be performed or els the said Order shalbe fourthwith afterwardes put in execucion
At this Pencion it is Ordered that wheras divers gentlemen of this Societie

hath not paid the severall soms of money taxed vppon them towardes the discharge of the Charges of the Late Maske, and by former Orders such of them as have Chambers should forfett ther Chambers and that they should be seised by the Pencion to the vse of the howse, and such of them as have noe Chambers should be expulsed, That if these gentlemen which have not hitherto paid ther severall taxes and money vppon them seised towardes the said Maske shall not paie the same before the accomptes vppon Saterday NextSaterday Next: 20 November 1613 to Sir ffrancis Eure knight that then every one of them Makinge default heerin shall have the said former Order strickly executed vppon them without any further delaye

At this Pencion it is Ordered that the execucion of [of] all the Orders here to fore made against the maskers for & towchinge the apparrell for the [Maskers] Maskinge is spared and remitted at this Pencion

div.head: f 304 (22 November)
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that all the admittance money of this terme now in the Stewardes handes and all the admittance money to be paied vnto the Steward the next Terme shalbe paid to Sir ffrancis Evre by the Steward towardes the debtes Owinge for the Maskers apparrell and the Owld Steward to acompt to Sir ffrancis Evre and to paie him also what is in his handes
Admittances to pay, the debtes arrere for the Maske.

It is at this Pencion also Ordered that all money ffor admittances shall ffrom hence ffourth be paid over to Sir ffrancis Evre to be imployed ffor the satisfaction of the remaining debtes of the howse for the Maske till the debtes be fully satisfied

div.head: f 304 (8 November) (Cupboard order)
div.ab: Eightly for that the disorders in the Christmas tyme may booth infecte the mynds and preiudice the estats & fortunes of the younger gentlemen in the same Societies It is Therfore Ordered that ther shalbe commons off the howse kept in every howse of Court duringe the Crismas and that none shall play in the severall halls at the dice except he be a gentleman of the sam Societie & in Commons & the benefitt of the boxes to goo to the Butlers of every howse Respectively.

div.head: f 312v (31 January) (Pension orders)
div.note: Musitians granted their Ordinary allowance, though Commons were broke vp
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that [that] the Musitions to have ther Ordinary allowance during Comons was broke vpe as they vsualy have had at other tymes

div.head: f 314 (17 October) (Pension orders)
div.note: The ‘Barriors’ (l.18 and subsequently) was a martial exercise presented jointly by the four Inns of Court to celebrate the investiture of Prince Charles as prince of Wales, at the Banqueting House, Whitehall, 4 November 1616: see Appendix 6.1 (under ‘Barriers’).
A Taxe for the Charge of the Barriors.
div.ab: At this Pencion every Reador Ancient Barrister and other gentleman that shalbe in the Towne betwene this and the end of Hillary terme or have any Chamber in the howse other of the house or by lease ortherwysefor otherwyse shal pay towards the Barriors intended to be presented before his Maiesti shall pay affter these Rats and proporcions followinge Every Reador or Ancient of the Bench xl s. every Ancient vnder the Bench xxx s. Every Barrister xx s. & Every other gentlemen xiij s. iiij d.

list.item: Mr Newton is appointed Collector of the Readors & Ancients
Mr Griffeth for of the Barristers
And Mr wrightington of the yonge gentlemen vnder the Barr

div.head: f 314v (8 November)
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that all such gentlemen of this Societie as are be hinde with ther taxacion towardes the barriers performed at the Courte yf they be in Commons they shall pay ther taxacion before fryday dinnor or els to put fourth of Commons, and that such as are forth of Commons shal pay ther taxacion before the next Pencion in the next weeke and those which shall not paye the same before the next pencion in the next weeke if they have howse Chambers or Chambers by lease in the howse shall forfet ther Chambers and if they have no Chambers then they shalbe forthfor shalbe put forth of the howse

div.head: f 315 (18 November)
div.note: such gentlemen to appere before the Bench in the hall, as pay not their taxe to the Barriors.
div.ab: It is Ordered at this Pencion that 12 of the Ancientest Comonors that ar behind with ther taxacion towards the barriors shall appeare before the Readors at the tables end to morrowe at Dinnor to shewe Cause why they pay it not and yf they do not pay nor shall give satisfaction why they doe it not, That they shall stand expelled fourth of this Societie And so all the rest of the Ancient Barristers and other gentlemen to appeare by 12 a day every day affter the other till they have all appeared and be in the same Case

div.note: Admittances this Terme for the Barriors.
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that all the moneys that shalbe Received this terme for admissions shalbe paid and deliuered to Sir Thomas Tildesley to be Imployed towardes the satisfaction of such as have Lent moneyes towards the performance of the Barriors

div.head: f 315v (21 May)
div.ab: At this Pencion it is Ordered that the moneys this terme Received for admittances shall goe and be imployed towards the payment of the Readors of such moneys as they have lent for the settinge forth of Barriors which is yet behinde
div.note: 3 l. 6 s. 5 d. per Annum allow to Michell the Musitian per vitam.
div.ab: It is Ordered at this Pencion that Mr Michell the Musition of the howse shall have allowed vnto him duringe his liffe five Markes to be paid every midsomer terme out of the first admittance money that shalbe that terme received

div.head: f i 22 October 1618
div.note: ‘Thomas Adson’ is possibly an error for John Adson (see printed Inns of Court, Volume 1, Introduction, p xxx).
div.ab: The Names of such as ar allowed by the Readors and have vndertaken to serve this howse with Musicke for this next yeare following for the Owld wages

persName.n: Thomas Adson - but possibly John Adson

div.head: f 351v (28 January) (Pension orders)
div.note: Aorder for mussitions
div.ab: The musisions [Peticion] have five poundes allowed them for the Last Crismas notwithstand Commons were [vp] broke vp and they did no servise

div.head: f 390v (3 February) (Pension orders)
div.note: Both the ‘Ante-maske’ and ‘Bakers reuells’ remain unaccounted for. On the one hand the most recent Gray’s Inn masque otherwise recorded is the Masque of Mountebanks of 2 and 19 February 1617/18 (see Appendix 6.1). On the other hand no Inn of Court presented a masque to Charles I prior to 1633–4 (see p 240, ll.4–6). Perhaps Gray’s Inn organized an entertainment this year for performance in its own hall but not repeated at court.
div.ab: The charge of the Hall & the Ante-maske to be cast into Commons./

div.note: Bakers Reuells to be kept this terme onely.
div.ab: It is ordered that Bakers reuells may be kept from henceforth this Terme time not withstanding former orders to the contrary saterday night next excepted, prouided alwayes that it be noe precident for any time after this Terme

div.head: ff 401–1v (9–14 November) (Pension orders)
div.note: The lower outside corner of the folio has been torn with much loss of text. Enough remains to show that the order was for an assessment toward the furnishing of the forthcoming masque, Shirley’s Triumph of Peace (see Appendix 6.1).

list.item: It is agreed that towards the furni now intended ther shall bee levyed
the Bench & of euery Barronet or the house 4 li. a man of euery
euery Barrister 40 s. & of euery yo presently of ech that is in towne
house mr Godbold & mr Rumsey for the Bench and knights
william Ward for the Auncients./
mr newdegate & mr Rutter for
mr Gulston mr wentworth & mr
And mr whitfeld is chosen Treasuror to whom these Collectors are to pay there monyes collected weekely

And power is giuen to mr whitfeld mr Brereton & mr dauison the three committees of this house for the Maske together with the other committees of the three other houses to agree with the said other committees of such things as they shall thinke fitt about the accomodation of the Maske./

mr Iones mr Hooker & mr Page three of the Attorneyes of hamber are to pay 3 li. a man towards the maske the chambers they hold there, & the Clarke amber to pay 4 li. & the Custos Breuiumsfor Breuium in respect of his office & the Clarke in respect of his office in Grayes in aunchients Collections & the 4ers Collections./
towards the maske are to pay seuerall collectors thereof by this day there seuerall Chambers to bee seased for forfeited./.

bee assistants and to pay there vacacions in & as they accept the said assistancey nd to present names of assistance Pencions the fower maskers & the 25 house that are to present the Masque nd to bee exempted from the Collection to the Masque./

It is Ordred that if any gentleman taxed to the masque shall faile to pay his tax before Thursday next21 November 1633 that then his Chamber if hee haue ^a Chamber shallbe seased as forfited And hee put out of Commons; And if hee haue noe Chamber & bee in Commons then hee shallbe put out of Commons & pay duble taxe. And if hee bee not in Commons hee shalbee Cast into Commons & kept in till hee haue payd his taxe double./
It is Ordred that mr William Greeke shall for refuseinge to bee an Assistant pay a fine of 50 li./
It is Ordred that mr Edward Ascough bee discharged of his being an Assistant./
It is Ordred that mr William Iackson & mr Richard Proctor bee called Assistants & are to bee warned to attend at the next Pencion
It is orderd that mr William Iackson bee discharged of his being an Assistant
Mr Iohn Onby is called an Assistant & is to attend at the next Pencion./.
Mr Richard Proctor hath accepted of his being Assistant

It is ordred that the Collectors for the masque shall on Satterday23 November 1633 dinner present the names of all such as haue not payd there tax, to the end that such as haue chambers in the house may haue the Chambers seased as forfayted & bee put out of Commons vntill they pay there respectiue taxes. And such as haue noe Chambers to bee put out of commons vntill they shall pay there taxes duble And such as bee not in Commons shall bee cast into commons & kept in vntill they pay there respectiue taxes duble./
It is Ordred that Mr Rutter bee added to the Committees to the Masque to assist them therein./

It is Ordred that mr Whitfeld may deliuer out any of the moneys which hee shall receiue towards the Masque vppon warrants to him to bee directed & seigned by any three of the Committees for the fower Howses of Court and that such deliuery vppon such warrant shallbe a discharge to him; neuerthelesse it is ordred hee may issue out any some not exceedinge xl s. & the same shallbe allowed him hee takeinge a receipt for the same vnder the parties hands that receues the same of him respectiuely.

It is ordred that towards the furnishing of the masque to be presented at Court ther shallbe leuied more then is formerly taxed of euery man halfe soe much as was formerly taxed vppon him; All these to bee leuied presently vnder the former penallty by the former Collectors respectiuely & payd to the Treasurer for the masque prouided that this tax shall not extend to any gentleman that is a Rider Masquer or shall Ryde to present the masque at Court./.

All gentlemen of this societie that are taxed to paye towards the masque are to make payment before ffryday31 January 1633/4 at night or otherwise they shall pay double & their Chambers to be seized./

It is ordered that all those who shall not pay their taxes for the masque formerly sett, before Thirsday6 February 1633/4 at noone next shall pay double taxes & their Chambers to be fourthwith seized & if they haue noe Chambers in the house then they are to be cast into Commons & continued in Commons vntill they shall pay their taxes double, & the Collectors are to present the names vpon Thirsday6 February 1633/4 at night of all such as shall not then haue paid their said taxes.

It is Orderd that towards the finishing of the masque & the new presentment therof to the King & Queenes Maiestie, ther shall be levyed more then is formerly taxed, soe much more as was taxed on them at the pencion holden the xxiij day of Ianuary last: All the said monyes to be paid vpon the former penalties to the former Collectors only mr Heilen is to Collect in the place of mr Wentworth who is out of Towne & the Collectors are to pay the monyes Collected as they shall be Collected to the Treasurer for the masque/. Prouided this Tax shall not extend to any gentleman is a masquer or Rydes to present the Masque./
It is Ordered that all the gentlemen of this societie shall before the end of this Terme pay their payments for the last masque or in default therof to be expelled this societie./
These gentlemen following are put out of Commons for not appeerance at this Pencion & not payment of their taxacions for the late masque videlicet. Mr Burwell Iunior Mr Earl George, Mr Richardson./

It is also orderd that all the gentlemen of the house who do not pay their taxacions for the late masque before Thirsday next,6 February 1633/4 their Chambers are to be seized to the vse of the house./
The Collectors by too morrow at dinner are to present the names of such as haue not paid their taxacions for the masque, & to be proceeded against, according to the last order./

div.head: f 405v
div.ab: These Gentlemen vnder written are cast into Commons and to be put out of Commons vntill they haue paide their double Taxes to the Masque videlicet.
These Gentlemen vnderwritten are to paie ther double Taxes to the Masque before Wednesday21 May 1634 Dinner or to be expeld the Howse

list.item: Bate Thomas and his Castings in./ Or his Bond to be sued

div.ab: Mr William Hughes and Mr Iohn Warrens Chambers to be seised for there Commons and there Taxes./

It is ordered that Mr Lawrence, Mr North Dudley, Mr Stewards Senior et Iunior, Mr Spencer Edward Mr Humphry Mackworth, Mr Simeon Brograue, Mr Henry Goldsmith Mr Thomas Procter Senior, Mr Tilney Senior, Mr Reuet Senior, Mr Thomas Marsh, Mr Dewell senior, and Mr Thomas Cole, theire Chambers shalbe seised for theire Taxacions to the Masque, and to paie double

list.item: Mr Necton to paie a double Taxe towards the Maske for his Contempt in refusinge to paie his Taxacion vppon request
Mr Tobias Rose to paie his Taxacion double of the Maske if he doth not paie his former taxacion by ffridaie next.13 June 1634
Mr Angeirs Chamber to be seised for not paiement of his Taxacion and Mr Carrills in like manner.
Mr Benefeild his Chamber to be seised for not payment of his Taxacion
Mr Polly Iunior his Chamber to be seised for the like
Mr Pecke the like.
Mr Ogle the like
Mr Walpoole Iohn the like
Mr Tailor Iohn the like.
Mr Bacon Walpoole if he doth not paie before ffridaie13 June 1634 to be cast and kept in Commons vntill he paie double
Mr Skeirne to be put out of Commons and paie double if he doth not paie on[t] ffridaie next
Mr Blewcoks Chamber to be seised for the like
Mr Thomas Cotton to be cast into Commons for the like,
Mr Chamberlaines Chamber to be seised and to paie double
Mr fforde the like
Mr Thomas ffaldoe the like
Mr William Gerrard the like
Mr Iames Harvie the like
Sir Edward fisher the like
Mr Thomas Hammon the like
Mr Heath the like
Mr Nicholas ffisher And Mr Tomline the like./.
The Cheife Butler is to send notice to all the Benchers and auncients ^&c: who haue not paied there Taxacions ^ towards the masque to paie the same with speed.
Committees to take the Accompts of Mr Whitefield concerninge the Masque money.
Mr Gerrard, Mr Rumsey, Mr Pheasante & Mr Brickenden or two of them./
The former Orders for such as haue not paide their partes to the charge to the late masque are renued and to bee put in execucion.
Mr Osbaldeston and Mr Rumsey are for this Societie to meete with the rest of the Committees for the Masque/
The account for the maske exhibited by master serieant whitfeild is allowed, & master serieant discharged therof/
Mr Reve & mr Bryan are to take mr Rumseyes account touching the masque./
The moneyes behind by any gentlemen toward the masque are to be gathered & Collected this Terme by Iohn Pecke the Butler or former orders therin to be put in execucion if payment be not made./

div.head: f 427* (1 June) (Pension orders)
div.note: No explanation is given for the appointment of Parker as master of the revels. Appointments to this office do not otherwise occur in Gray’s Inn accounts.
Mr Parker Master of the Revells, in Mr Edward Page his Roome.
div.ab: It is ordered that Mr Henry Parker shall bee Master of the Revells in the Roome of Mr Edward Page.
